summary.long: Ecclesiastes is a book of the Old Testament.

verses.text: The words of the Teacher, son of David, king of Jerusalem:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘Meaningless! Meaningless!’
    says the Teacher.
‘Utterly meaningless!
    Everything is meaningless.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
What do people gain from all their labours
    at which they toil under the sun?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Generations come and generations go,
    but the earth remains for ever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sun rises and the sun sets,
    and hurries back to where it rises.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The wind blows to the south
    and turns to the north;
round and round it goes,
    ever returning on its course.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
All streams flow into the sea,
    yet the sea is never full.
To the place the streams come from,
    there they return again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
All things are wearisome,
    more than one can say.
The eye never has enough of seeing,
    nor the ear its fill of hearing.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Is there anything of which one can say,
    ‘Look! This is something new’?
It was here already, long ago;
    it was here before our time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
No one remembers the former generations,
    and even those yet to come
will not be remembered
    by those who follow them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I, the Teacher, was king over Israel in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I applied my mind to study and to explore by wisdom all that is done under the heavens. What a heavy burden God has laid on mankind!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have seen all the things that are done under the sun; all of them are meaningless, a chasing after the wind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
What is crooked cannot be straightened;
    what is lacking cannot be counted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I said to myself, ‘Look, I have increased in wisdom more than anyone who has ruled over Jerusalem before me; I have experienced much of wisdom and knowledge.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I applied myself to the understanding of wisdom, and also of madness and folly, but I learned that this, too, is a chasing after the wind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For with much wisdom comes much sorrow;
    the more knowledge, the more grief.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I said to myself, ‘Come now, I will test you with pleasure to find out what is good.’ But that also proved to be meaningless.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Laughter,’ I said, ‘is madness. And what does pleasure accomplish?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I tried cheering myself with wine, and embracing folly – my mind still guiding me with wisdom. I wanted to see what was good for people to do under the heavens during the few days of their lives.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I undertook great projects: I built houses for myself and planted vineyards.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I made gardens and parks and planted all kinds of fruit trees in them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I made reservoirs to water groves of flourishing trees.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I bought male and female slaves and had other slaves who were born in my house. I also owned more herds and flocks than anyone in Jerusalem before me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I amassed silver and gold for myself, and the treasure of kings and provinces. I acquired male and female singers, and a harem as well – the delights of a man’s heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I became greater by far than anyone in Jerusalem before me. In all this my wisdom stayed with me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I denied myself nothing my eyes desired;
    I refused my heart no pleasure.
My heart took delight in all my labour,
    and this was the reward for all my toil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yet when I surveyed all that my hands had done
    and what I had toiled to achieve,
everything was meaningless, a chasing after the wind;
    nothing was gained under the sun.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then I turned my thoughts to consider wisdom,
    and also madness and folly.
What more can the king’s successor do
    than what has already been done?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I saw that wisdom is better than folly,
    just as light is better than darkness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The wise have eyes in their heads,
    while the fool walks in the darkness;
but I came to realise
    that the same fate overtakes them both.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then I said to myself,
‘The fate of the fool will overtake me also.
    What then do I gain by being wise?’
I said to myself,
    ‘This too is meaningless.’
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text: So I hated life, because the work that is done under the sun was grievous to me. All of it is meaningless, a chasing after the wind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I hated all the things I had toiled for under the sun, because I must leave them to the one who comes after me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And who knows whether that person will be wise or foolish? Yet they will have control over all the fruit of my toil into which I have poured my effort and skill under the sun. This too is meaningless.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So my heart began to despair over all my toilsome labour under the sun.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For a person may labour with wisdom, knowledge and skill, and then they must leave all they own to another who has not toiled for it. This too is meaningless and a great misfortune.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: What do people get for all the toil and anxious striving with which they labour under the sun?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All their days their work is grief and pain; even at night their minds do not rest. This too is meaningless.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A person can do nothing better than to eat and drink and find satisfaction in their own toil. This too, I see, is from the hand of God,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: for without him, who can eat or find enjoyment?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: To the person who pleases him, God gives wisdom, knowledge and happiness, but to the sinner he gives the task of gathering and storing up wealth to hand it over to the one who pleases God. This too is meaningless, a chasing after the wind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There is a time for everything,
    and a season for every activity under the heavens:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
a time to be born and a time to die,
    a time to plant and a time to uproot,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
a time to kill and a time to heal,
    a time to tear down and a time to build,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
a time to weep and a time to laugh,
    a time to mourn and a time to dance,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
a time to scatter stones and a time to gather them,
    a time to embrace and a time to refrain from embracing,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
a time to search and a time to give up,
    a time to keep and a time to throw away,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
a time to tear and a time to mend,
    a time to be silent and a time to speak,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
a time to love and a time to hate,
    a time for war and a time for peace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: What do workers gain from their toil?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have seen the burden God has laid on the human race.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He has made everything beautiful in its time. He has also set eternity in the human heart; yet no one can fathom what God has done from beginning to end.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I know that there is nothing better for people than to be happy and to do good while they live.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That each of them may eat and drink, and find satisfaction in all their toil – this is the gift of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I know that everything God does will endure for ever; nothing can be added to it and nothing taken from it. God does it so that people will fear him.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
And I saw something else under the sun:
in the place of judgment – wickedness was there,
    in the place of justice – wickedness was there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I said to myself,
‘God will bring into judgment
    both the righteous and the wicked,
for there will be a time for every activity,
    a time to judge every deed.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I also said to myself, ‘As for humans, God tests them so that they may see that they are like the animals.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Surely the fate of human beings is like that of the animals; the same fate awaits them both: as one dies, so dies the other. All have the same breath; humans have no advantage over animals. Everything is meaningless.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All go to the same place; all come from dust, and to dust all return.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Who knows if the human spirit rises upward and if the spirit of the animal goes down into the earth?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I saw that there is nothing better for a person than to enjoy their work, because that is their lot. For who can bring them to see what will happen after them?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Again I looked and saw all the oppression that was taking place under the sun:
I saw the tears of the oppressed –
    and they have no comforter;
power was on the side of their oppressors –
    and they have no comforter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
And I declared that the dead,
    who had already died,
are happier than the living,
    who are still alive.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But better than both
    is the one who has never been born,
who has not seen the evil
    that is done under the sun.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I saw that all toil and all achievement spring from one person’s envy of another. This too is meaningless, a chasing after the wind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Fools fold their hands
    and ruin themselves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Better one handful with tranquillity
    than two handfuls with toil
    and chasing after the wind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Again I saw something meaningless under the sun:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
there was a man all alone;
    he had neither son nor brother.
There was no end to his toil,
    yet his eyes were not content with his wealth.
‘For whom am I toiling,’ he asked,
    ‘and why am I depriving myself of enjoyment?’
This too is meaningless –
    a miserable business!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Two are better than one,
    because they have a good return for their labour:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
if either of them falls down,
    one can help the other up.
But pity anyone who falls
    and has no one to help them up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Also, if two lie down together, they will keep warm.
    But how can one keep warm alone?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Though one may be overpowered,
    two can defend themselves.
A cord of three strands is not quickly broken.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Better a poor but wise youth than an old but foolish king who no longer knows how to heed a warning.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The youth may have come from prison to the kingship, or he may have been born in poverty within his kingdom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I saw that all who lived and walked under the sun followed the youth, the king’s successor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was no end to all the people who were before them. But those who came later were not pleased with the successor. This too is meaningless, a chasing after the wind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Guard your steps when you go to the house of God. Go near to listen rather than to offer the sacrifice of fools, who do not know that they do wrong.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not be quick with your mouth,
    do not be hasty in your heart
    to utter anything before God.
God is in heaven
    and you are on earth,
    so let your words be few.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A dream comes when there are many cares,
    and many words mark the speech of a fool.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When you make a vow to God, do not delay to fulfil it. He has no pleasure in fools; fulfil your vow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It is better not to make a vow than to make one and not fulfil it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do not let your mouth lead you into sin. And do not protest to the temple messenger, ‘My vow was a mistake.’ Why should God be angry at what you say and destroy the work of your hands?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Much dreaming and many words are meaningless. Therefore fear God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you see the poor oppressed in a district, and justice and rights denied, do not be surprised at such things; for one official is eyed by a higher one, and over them both are others higher still.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The increase from the land is taken by all; the king himself profits from the fields.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
As goods increase,
    so do those who consume them.
And what benefit are they to the owners
    except to feast their eyes on them?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sleep of a labourer is sweet,
    whether they eat little or much,
but as for the rich, their abundance
    permits them no sleep.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I have seen a grievous evil under the sun:
wealth hoarded to the harm of its owners,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
or wealth lost through some misfortune,
so that when they have children
    there is nothing left for them to inherit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Everyone comes naked from their mother’s womb,
    and as everyone comes, so they depart.
They take nothing from their toil
    that they can carry in their hands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This too is a grievous evil:
as everyone comes, so they depart,
    and what do they gain,
    since they toil for the wind?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
All their days they eat in darkness,
    with great frustration, affliction and anger.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what I have observed to be good: that it is appropriate for a person to eat, to drink and to find satisfaction in their toilsome labour under the sun during the few days of life God has given them – for this is their lot.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moreover, when God gives someone wealth and possessions, and the ability to enjoy them, to accept their lot and be happy in their toil – this is a gift of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They seldom reflect on the days of their life, because God keeps them occupied with gladness of heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have seen another evil under the sun, and it weighs heavily on mankind:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God gives some people wealth, possessions and honour, so that they lack nothing their hearts desire, but God does not grant them the ability to enjoy them, and strangers enjoy them instead. This is meaningless, a grievous evil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A man may have a hundred children and live many years; yet no matter how long he lives, if he cannot enjoy his prosperity and does not receive proper burial, I say that a stillborn child is better off than he.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It comes without meaning, it departs in darkness, and in darkness its name is shrouded.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Though it never saw the sun or knew anything, it has more rest than does that man –
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: even if he lives a thousand years twice over but fails to enjoy his prosperity. Do not all go to the same place?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Everyone’s toil is for their mouth,
    yet their appetite is never satisfied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
What advantage have the wise over fools?
What do the poor gain
    by knowing how to conduct themselves before others?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Better what the eye sees
    than the roving of the appetite.
This too is meaningless,
    a chasing after the wind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Whatever exists has already been named,
    and what humanity is has been known;
no one can contend
    with someone who is stronger.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The more the words,
    the less the meaning,
    and how does that profit anyone?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For who knows what is good for a person in life, during the few and meaningless days they pass through like a shadow? Who can tell them what will happen under the sun after they are gone?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A good name is better than fine perfume,
    and the day of death better than the day of birth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It is better to go to a house of mourning
    than to go to a house of feasting,
for death is the destiny of everyone;
    the living should take this to heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Frustration is better than laughter,
    because a sad face is good for the heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The heart of the wise is in the house of mourning,
    but the heart of fools is in the house of pleasure.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It is better to heed the rebuke of a wise person
    than to listen to the song of fools.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like the crackling of thorns under the pot,
    so is the laughter of fools.
    This too is meaningless.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Extortion turns a wise person into a fool,
    and a bribe corrupts the heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The end of a matter is better than its beginning,
    and patience is better than pride.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not be quickly provoked in your spirit,
    for anger resides in the lap of fools.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not say, ‘Why were the old days better than these?’
    For it is not wise to ask such questions.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Wisdom, like an inheritance, is a good thing
    and benefits those who see the sun.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Wisdom is a shelter
    as money is a shelter,
but the advantage of knowledge is this:
    wisdom preserves those who have it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Consider what God has done:
who can straighten
    what he has made crooked?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When times are good, be happy;
    but when times are bad, consider this:
God has made the one
    as well as the other.
Therefore, no one can discover
    anything about their future.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In this meaningless life of mine I have seen both of these:
the righteous perishing in their righteousness,
    and the wicked living long in their wickedness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not be over-righteous,
    neither be overwise –
    why destroy yourself?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not be overwicked,
    and do not be a fool –
    why die before your time?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It is good to grasp the one
    and not let go of the other.
    Whoever fears God will avoid all extremes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Wisdom makes one wise person more powerful
    than ten rulers in a city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Indeed, there is no one on earth who is righteous,
    no one who does what is right and never sins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not pay attention to every word people say,
    or you may hear your servant cursing you –
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
for you know in your heart
    that many times you yourself have cursed others.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
All this I tested by wisdom and I said,
‘I am determined to be wise’–
    but this was beyond me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Whatever exists is far off and most profound –
    who can discover it?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So I turned my mind to understand,
    to investigate and to search out wisdom and the scheme of things
and to understand the stupidity of wickedness
    and the madness of folly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I find more bitter than death
    the woman who is a snare,
whose heart is a trap
    and whose hands are chains.
The man who pleases God will escape her,
    but the sinner she will ensnare.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘Look,’ says the Teacher, ‘this is what I have discovered:
‘Adding one thing to another to discover the scheme of things –
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
while I was still searching
    but not finding –
I found one upright man among a thousand,
    but not one upright woman among them all.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This only have I found:
    God created mankind upright,
    but they have gone in search of many schemes.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who is like the wise?
    Who knows the explanation of things?
A person’s wisdom brightens their face
    and changes its hard appearance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Obey the king’s command, I say, because you took an oath before God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do not be in a hurry to leave the king’s presence. Do not stand up for a bad cause, for he will do whatever he pleases.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Since a king’s word is supreme, who can say to him, ‘What are you doing?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Whoever obeys his command will come to no harm,
    and the wise heart will know the proper time and procedure.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For there is a proper time and procedure for every matter,
    though a person may be weighed down by misery.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Since no one knows the future,
    who can tell someone else what is to come?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As no one has power over the wind to contain it,
    so no one has power over the time of their death.
As no one is discharged in time of war,
    so wickedness will not release those who practise it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All this I saw, as I applied my mind to everything done under the sun. There is a time when a man lords it over others to his own hurt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then too, I saw the wicked buried – those who used to come and go from the holy place and receive praise in the city where they did this. This too is meaningless.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the sentence for a crime is not quickly carried out, people’s hearts are filled with schemes to do wrong.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Although a wicked person who commits a hundred crimes may live a long time, I know that it will go better with those who fear God, who are reverent before him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yet because the wicked do not fear God, it will not go well with them, and their days will not lengthen like a shadow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There is something else meaningless that occurs on earth: the righteous who get what the wicked deserve, and the wicked who get what the righteous deserve. This too, I say, is meaningless.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I commend the enjoyment of life, because there is nothing better for a person under the sun than to eat and drink and be glad. Then joy will accompany them in their toil all the days of the life God has given them under the sun.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When I applied my mind to know wisdom and to observe the labour that is done on earth – people getting no sleep day or night –
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then I saw all that God has done. No one can comprehend what goes on under the sun. Despite all their efforts to search it out, no one can discover its meaning. Even if the wise claim they know, they cannot really comprehend it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I reflected on all this and concluded that the righteous and the wise and what they do are in God’s hands, but no one knows whether love or hate awaits them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
All share a common destiny – the righteous and the wicked, the good and the bad, the clean and the unclean, those who offer sacrifices and those who do not.
As it is with the good,
    so with the sinful;
as it is with those who take oaths,
    so with those who are afraid to take them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is the evil in everything that happens under the sun: The same destiny overtakes all. The hearts of people, moreover, are full of evil and there is madness in their hearts while they live, and afterwards they join the dead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Anyone who is among the living has hope – even a live dog is better off than a dead lion!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For the living know that they will die,
    but the dead know nothing;
they have no further reward,
    and even their name is forgotten.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Their love, their hate
    and their jealousy have long since vanished;
never again will they have a part
    in anything that happens under the sun.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Go, eat your food with gladness, and drink your wine with a joyful heart, for God has already approved what you do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Always be clothed in white, and always anoint your head with oil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Enjoy life with your wife, whom you love, all the days of this meaningless life that God has given you under the sun – all your meaningless days. For this is your lot in life and in your toilsome labour under the sun.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whatever your hand finds to do, do it with all your might, for in the realm of the dead, where you are going, there is neither working nor planning nor knowledge nor wisdom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I have seen something else under the sun:
The race is not to the swift
    or the battle to the strong,
nor does food come to the wise
    or wealth to the brilliant
    or favour to the learned;
but time and chance happen to them all.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Moreover, no one knows when their hour will come:
As fish are caught in a cruel net,
    or birds are taken in a snare,
so people are trapped by evil times
    that fall unexpectedly upon them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I also saw under the sun this example of wisdom that greatly impressed me:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: there was once a small city with only a few people in it. And a powerful king came against it, surrounded it and built huge siege works against it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now there lived in that city a man poor but wise, and he saved the city by his wisdom. But nobody remembered that poor man.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I said, ‘Wisdom is better than strength.’ But the poor man’s wisdom is despised, and his words are no longer heeded.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The quiet words of the wise are more to be heeded
    than the shouts of a ruler of fools.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Wisdom is better than weapons of war,
    but one sinner destroys much good.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As dead flies give perfume a bad smell,
    so a little folly outweighs wisdom and honour.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The heart of the wise inclines to the right,
    but the heart of the fool to the left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Even as fools walk along the road,
    they lack sense
    and show everyone how stupid they are.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
There is an evil I have seen under the sun,
    the sort of error that arises from a ruler:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
fools are put in many high positions,
    while the rich occupy the low ones.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I have seen slaves on horseback,
    while princes go on foot like slaves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Whoever digs a pit may fall into it;
    whoever breaks through a wall may be bitten by a snake.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Whoever quarries stones may be injured by them;
    whoever splits logs may be endangered by them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If the axe is dull
    and its edge unsharpened,
more strength is needed,
    but skill will bring success.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If a snake bites before it is charmed,
    the charmer receives no fee.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Words from the mouth of the wise are gracious,
    but fools are consumed by their own lips.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
At the beginning their words are folly;
    at the end they are wicked madness –
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
and fools multiply words.
No one knows what is coming –
    who can tell someone else what will happen after them?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The toil of fools wearies them;
    they do not know the way to town.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Woe to the land whose king was a servant
    and whose princes feast in the morning.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Blessed is the land whose king is of noble birth
    and whose princes eat at a proper time –
    for strength and not for drunkenness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Through laziness, the rafters sag;
    because of idle hands, the house leaks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A feast is made for laughter,
    wine makes life merry,
    and money is the answer for everything.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not revile the king even in your thoughts,
    or curse the rich in your bedroom,
because a bird in the sky may carry your words,
    and a bird on the wing may report what you say.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Ship your grain across the sea;
    after many days you may receive a return.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Invest in seven ventures, yes, in eight;
    you do not know what disaster may come upon the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If clouds are full of water,
    they pour rain on the earth.
Whether a tree falls to the south or to the north,
    in the place where it falls, there it will lie.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Whoever watches the wind will not plant;
    whoever looks at the clouds will not reap.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As you do not know the path of the wind,
    or how the body is formed in a mother’s womb,
so you cannot understand the work of God,
    the Maker of all things.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Sow your seed in the morning,
    and at evening let your hands not be idle,
for you do not know which will succeed,
    whether this or that,
    or whether both will do equally well.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Light is sweet,
    and it pleases the eyes to see the sun.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
However many years anyone may live,
    let them enjoy them all.
But let them remember the days of darkness,
    for there will be many.
    Everything to come is meaningless.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You who are young, be happy while you are young,
    and let your heart give you joy in the days of your youth.
Follow the ways of your heart
    and whatever your eyes see,
but know that for all these things
    God will bring you into judgment.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So then, banish anxiety from your heart
    and cast off the troubles of your body,
    for youth and vigour are meaningless.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Remember your Creator
    in the days of your youth,
before the days of trouble come
    and the years approach when you will say,
    ‘I find no pleasure in them’–
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
when the keepers of the house tremble,
    and the strong men stoop,
when the grinders cease because they are few,
    and those looking through the windows grow dim;
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
when people are afraid of heights
    and of dangers in the streets;
when the almond tree blossoms
    and the grasshopper drags itself along
    and desire no longer is stirred.
Then people go to their eternal home
    and mourners go about the streets.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Remember him – before the silver cord is severed,
    and the golden bowl is broken;
before the pitcher is shattered at the spring,
    and the wheel broken at the well,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
and the dust returns to the ground it came from,
    and the spirit returns to God who gave it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘Meaningless! Meaningless!’ says the Teacher.
    ‘Everything is meaningless!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Not only was the Teacher wise, but also he imparted knowledge to the people. He pondered and searched out and set in order many proverbs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Teacher searched to find just the right words, and what he wrote was upright and true.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The words of the wise are like goads, their collected sayings like firmly embedded nails – given by one shepherd.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Be warned, my son, of anything in addition to them.
Of making many books there is no end, and much study wearies the body.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Now all has been heard;
    here is the conclusion of the matter:
fear God and keep his commandments,
    for this is the duty of all mankind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For God will bring every deed into judgment,
    including every hidden thing,
    whether it is good or evil.
verses.speaker: Narrator
